Description: Fragment from rim of a mould-made terracotta vessel, perhaps a perirrhanterion. Upper surface is that of a shallow bowl; the small part of the underside that is preserved is flat; some form of vertical support runs from bowl down to the underside. Stamped decoration consisting of frieze of tongues above a wave pattern ('running dog'). Thin yellow slip. Dense pale yellow-brown fabric with coarse white and dark grey inclusions. Corinthian pottery tile fabric.
Curator's comments: For a discussion on stamped tongue patterns on Corinthian pottery, see Weinberg, 'Corinthian Relief Ware: Pre-Hellenistic Period', Hesperia: The Journal of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens (1954), vol. 23, no. 2, p. 128-9, pl. 28, f, g; pl. 29, f. British Museum 1965,0930.541 probably comes from the same vessel.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GT.07)
